results.title: I spell I can't...I can!
results.creator_credit: Edie Collet, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Edie Collet’s beginnings were difficult - her mother died giving birth and she was diagnosed as being handicapped. Collet was raised by her father and siblings to become an educated, well travelled and independent adult. Collet was told she would never work but she proved them wrong. This story is dedicated to Collet’s dad.

results.title: Days of clear water
results.creator_credit: Emma Case, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Emma describes her life growing up with her nan, an independent lady who loved to tend to her garden and go for walks along the river. When her nan passed away, Emma lost not only her nan but her best friend.

group_works.creator_credit: Hazel Wilkinson and British Film Institute

results.title: 3.10 to Yuma [study extract] = Three ten to Yuma
results.creator_credit: Hazel Wilkinson and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
John Freeman discusses the film “3.10 to Yuma”, an example of the “psychological western”. He illustrates three important functions of the critic; analysis, interpretation and evaluation. Shows that criticism can be both entertaining in itself, and increase the pleasure obtained from the film. He avoids talking down to his audience yet he conveys a sense of authority. He exposes the cliche, which even the serious western cannot escape, with considerable humour.

results.title: Twelve angry men [study extract]
results.creator_credit: Hazel Wilkinson and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Arnot Robertson analyses the film “Twelve Angry Men”, directed by Sidney Lumet, produced by Henry Fonda and Reginald Rose, as a ‘writer’s play’, concerened less with story and action than with character. Uses excerpts from the film to illustrate the development of the various characters and compares the opening and closing scenes.

results.title: Odd man out: a critique [study extract]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Basil Wright analyses Carol Reed’s direction in “The Odd Man Out”. He traces, with the help of blackboard illustrations, the time limits of the story in connection with the movements of Johnny (James Mason), the main character. This main storyline is impinged upon by other characters at various times, the total dramatic impulse being carried forward by these contacts with the hunted man. Mr. Wright then breaks down sequences to scenes, then to shots, underlining his reasons for claiming the title of “masterpiece” for the film. Scenes are shown ‘silent’ and the subsequent showing of a sound version demonstrates the director’s use of unseen factors and sound to lift tension.

results.title: The Overlanders [study extract]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Dilys Powell, a film critic of the London Sunday Times, analyses the editing of a series of sequences in the Ealing Studio’s 1946 production of “The Overlanders”, directed by Harry Watt. Using the cattle stampede sequences as an example, she shows how the editor obtains his effects by the selection of images and sounds, and points out that the order and length of the shots create a narrative rhythm especially suited to the subject matter of the sequence.

results.title: Great expectations [study extract]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Critic and the Film”.
Analyses the opening scene from the Cineguild Production directed by David Lean. Shows how strong dramatic effect is achieved. Indicates in what ways the director’s treatment and editing are contrary to the expected rules.

results.title: Ian Botham
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cricketing legends”.
Richie Benaud and Jim Laker examine the cricketing achievements of one of the greatest all-rounders - Ian Botham. A controversial and colourful figure both on and off the field, Botham was a talented player who took some unbelievable catches in the slips and at the time of this programs’ production, was the only cricketer to score 5000 runs and take 300 wickets in Test Matches. Botham played for England and for the counties of Somerset and Worcestershire, making his debut in first-class cricket in the 1977 winning Ashes series. The highlights of Botham’s career are interspersed with an interview between Botham and Benaud.

group_siblings.title: Dennis Lillee

results.title: Dennis Lillee
results.creator_credit: John E. Bodnar and BBC Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cricketing legends”.
One of cricket’s greatest bowlers, with his thick moustache and bristling aggression, Dennis Lillee was both brilliant and charismatic. His new ball partnership with Jeff Thomson was, perhaps, the most feared in the modern game. Courageous, controversial, and always determined, Lillee overcame serious injury to complete a very distinguished career. This program includes a contribution from Rod Marsh who caught 95 catches from Lillee’s bowling.
